Photo: Johndavid Scarcliff Courtesy Of The Tobin Center Image 39 of 39 REVIEW: Lionel Richie ‘All Night Long’ – almost 1 / 39 Back to Gallery SAN ANTONIO – Lionel Richie doesn’t do encores. But he does make generations of women swoon. Several minutes after the pop superstar, activist and award-winning songwriter closed his sold-out concert Thursday at the Tobin Center for the Performing Arts -- and even after the lights went up -- several hundred ardent fans kept clapping and whopping it up.
Maybe it’s because he closed with “All Night Long.”
Richie was the star attraction at the Tobin Center’s second annual benefit concert. Last year, it was Sir Paul McCartney.
The sold-out concert attracted 1,750 well-heeled patrons. It marked the 28th sold-out concert at the venue since it opened last year.
Since then, more than a quarter million tickets have been sold for its various events.
Richie, backed by a five-piece band, opened with “Running with the Night” and “Penny Lover.” The one-two punch had fans on their feet. A small group of women on the front row, right at his feet, swayed and posed for selfies with Richie in the background.
“This is the most beautiful building I’ve seen in a long, long time,” Richie said, adding that he was going to spread the word among his friends “that this is the building to play.”
The Spurs Tony Parker was in the house as was businessman Ernesto Ancira and his wife, Robyn.
Richie relied heavily on his Commodores catalog, and “Easy,” the monster hit from the late ’70s, came early with the singer performing from behind a grand piano. He threw in a snippet of “My Love,” too.
Like McCartney, Richie uses young musicians to add a little extra kick here and there. While the singer was in fine voice, and dancing and hamming it up, his greatest asset may be his gift for gab and engaging the audience.
His self-deprecating humor poked fun at his image as a syrupy balladeer.
Richie sang three songs that he guaranteed were perfect for certain moments – “Lady” (for when it’s over), “Oh No” (for when one sees their baby another person) and “Stuck On You” (for when you’re in love).
“Who you gonna call?” he joked. When the audience shouted out his name, Richie just smiled and replied, “Damn right you are.”
He picked up the pace with “Dancing on the Ceiling,” which included a taste of Van Halen’s “Jump.”
The hits kept coming. “Three Times a Lady” was followed by “Sail On,” “Fancy Dancer,” “Sweet Love,” “Lady” and “Just to be Close to You.”
A funky and thumping “Brick House” added a little grit to the sometimes overly sweet set list. It was short-lived. The night ended with his biggest middle-of-the-road hits – “Say You, Say Me,” “Hello” (which may never be heard quite the same after Richie’s hilarious appearance on the “The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon”) and “All Night Long.”
As he joked earlier in the night, there was a time with his days in the Commodore when all night long, “meant all night long.”
But 20 songs wasn’t exactly a speed date.
hsaldana@express-news.net
